Reminiscences of Henry Ellsworth Earl
Pioneer Place,
Weyburn,
Sask.

Reminiscences of Henry Ellsworth Earl
This note found in the belongings of the deceased.

Admiral Earl May has been interested to hear. He resided here at Pioneer Place, Weyburn for months of life.
This note found in the belongings of the deceased.

Henry Earl may be of interest to you. He resided here at Pioneer Place, Wayburn the last few months of life.
Pamgarry Bank June 27, 1960

9th Henry Ellsworth Earle residing
on S.W. 1/4, 21. We were living at present do-
ing a summer out of doors in the old house at
Badwood. We were by hand was being
contaminated. Came west to go to Missouri but stayed
in Kansas in 1904. Worked in the district farm
until coming back to the hills first in
the late fall of 1905. Spent without trouble
to the hills in the spring by way of
my brother's farm to his homestead 6½
6.9.20 we moved and went to south
winter winter 1906-07 on SE 7-8-20 having
feed at Cranberry. Kept our own cattle. Shod top horses and
cold for 115 head cattle. Buzhired and put
some calves killed by cow in calf pen
Bought 85 through winter. Some real thin
changed a ride to yellow grass with
after fall haying 30.8.21 and two boys
Pamgarry Bank

June 27, 1960

Henry Ellsworth Earl Roadding

On S.W. 1/4 of 9.21, we moved out pregnant do-

laying out of doors in the gloomy old

out building (not made by hands) was born

on January 28th, 1905. Worked in the distillery farm

until spring of 1905. Spent without coming

to the hills in the spring by way of my

my brother's home to be homesteaded by

6.9.20 we sold out until June to south.

winter winter 1906-07 on SE.7-1-20 having

feed at Charles Kavanagh ranch of 8 head cows

cold for 115 head cattle. Buried at age 3

Some calves killed by came in of only four

B bought 85 through winter. Summered them

changed a ride to yellow grass with

father Paulding, 30.8.21 and two boys.
June 27, 1960

Dear Mr. Ellsworth,

I am writing to you from our new home in California. We have just moved into our new house and I wanted to let you know how much we appreciate your kindness and support during this time.

We have been very busy settling into our new life here. The weather has been quite pleasant so far, but we are looking forward to exploring all that California has to offer.

Thank you again for your friendship and understanding.

Sincerely,

[Signature]

P.S. We will be visiting you soon!
June 27, 1960

Dear Mr. Ellsworth,

I am writing this letter to inform you about our recent trip to Canada. We left on June 15th and returned on June 25th. We visited several cities in Ontario, including Toronto and Ottawa. The weather was very pleasant during our stay.

We also visited Niagara Falls, which was quite impressive. We stayed at a hotel near the falls and enjoyed the view from our room.

We hope to visit you soon and would be happy to bring some souvenirs from our trip.

Best regards,

[Signature]

P.S. We will be returning to Canada next year and would love to meet you then.
Onida & Pete got to Rough Back at dark night day and back track to Allan & B. started the experiment of roughing out of the much trouble they had before. We halted where broken through. If we pull our dogs on dry footing and place to sleep after traveling much often that were driving all night. Some being cold we water 20 times. All came around with plenty of Paw cake sugar and hot drink forgotten which remained us and we slept good start for Yellow Grass we camping again find a place to cross Rough back in daylight. Continue travel through mound water gant any hour for and I believe we pass somewhere by Badger creek and should at the lake, you see the way before we made better headway to Y. Grass without mentioning the other part of the Paw lake family around April 9th.
On the 2nd day we got back at dark. We had to walk back to the camp. We walked all night and got there before sunrise. After much trouble getting the family out of the hole where they were trapped, we walked two miles to get back to camp. We walked through the water up to our knees many times until we got to camp. All were very glad with plenty of rain which provided us with plenty of water. We continued our journey again and found a place to cross Rough Rock in daylight. Continue travel through our land and believe we passed somewhere by Bald Mountain and should be near the lake. You must have been very close when we arrived there. The other boat was off the Poveshull family around and got off.
Onida & Pete got to Rough back at
dark. Water deep and rough. Likely
back track to Allan. Milk plentiful before
out of kala where break through. Also pull
our halter other two pull tale. Got horses
in and fed. Our dogs on dry footing and
place to sleep of the tent. Very muddy after
what were watching all night frame living in
cold, live water. No blankets. Allan was very shaky
with plenty of Pan cake, sugar and hot drinks
for get which reminded us and we also got
start for yellow grass in morning again
find a path back to cross Rough back in
daylight. Continue travel through mound
water I cant any how far and I believe
we pass cornucopia by Badger on the way
ground at the lake. You must have one I believe
we made butte heading to Yippee
will see you joined the other party of
the Paulding family around April 9th
Onida & Pete got to Rough Bank at dark. Water deep and not easy to cross. Before back track to Allan's place. After getting there found plenty of homestead growing good out of hole where break through. Got two pull oxen halter other two pull tale. Got house me and fed. We did go on dry footing and place to sleep often too muddy after family through winter. Up to badly dry on days that were having little snow living on cold ice water 20 minutes. Allan was working hard with plenty of rain water, very cold and hot during got yet which remained us and we also good start for Yellow Grass in morning again found a place to cross Rough Bank in daylight. Continue travel through around waters I don't say how far and I believe we passed someplace by Badger in the am ground at the lakes. You know there going believe we made better heading away to Ygnola will we rejoined the other boys of the Pawnee family around April 9th.
Oxford

No. 613 S
